Sure, seasonal eating is a food tradition that has been influenced by agriculture. Here are a few examples of how it has become a food tradition:

1. Farm-to-Table Dining: One of the recent trends in the culinary world is the farm-to-table movement, which emphasizes the use of locally-sourced ingredients that are in season. Chefs often work directly with local farmers to source ingredients that are at their peak freshness and flavor, and create menus that change with the seasons.

2. Seasonal Produce Markets: Farmers' markets and seasonal produce markets have also become an important part of many communities, providing consumers with access to fresh, locally-grown produce. These markets often feature a variety of fruits and vegetables that are in season, and shoppers can use the opportunity to try new recipes and cooking techniques with the season's offerings.

3. Seasonal Festivals: Harvest festivals and other seasonal celebrations are also part of many food cultures around the world. These festivals typically feature local foods and dishes that are associated with a particular season or harvest. For example, the Mid-Autumn Festival, a popular festival in many East Asian cultures, is associated with mooncakes, a dessert that is eaten during the autumn harvest season.

Overall, seasonal eating has become a food tradition because it helps us connect with the natural rhythm of the seasons and the cycles of growth and harvest. By eating foods that are in season, we can enjoy fresh, flavorful dishes that are at their peak of taste and nutrition.
